Name: Galaxolide
Description: Galaxolide is an organic heterotricyclic compound that is 1,3,4,6,7,8-hexahydrocyclopenta[g]isochromene substituted by methyl groups at positions 4, 6, 6, 7, 8 and 8 respectively. It is a synthetic musk used as a fragrance in cosmetics. It has a role as a fragrance. It is a member of isochromenes and an organic heterotricyclic compound.

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Nakata H et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 2216-22 (2007)
animal_concentrations.Value: Galaxolide concentrations in shallow water marine organisms from the Ariake Sea, Japan, collected in 2004. The concentration of galaxolide in the blubber of finless porpoises and striped dolphins collected from Japanese coastal waters from 1977 through 2005 ranged from 3.7 to 28 ng/g wet wt; min concentration of <0.8 in striped dolphin in 1980 and a max of 52 ng/g wet wt in finless porpoise reported in 2003. Other marine mammal concentrations were (species; location; year; concn (ng/g wet wt)(1):

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Fromme H et al; Polycyclic musk fragrances in water and fish samples from Berlin. In: Amer. Chem. Soc., Div. Environ. Chem., preprint extend. Abstr., 217th ACS Nat. Meet., vol 39, pp. 183-4. (1999) (2) Gatermann R et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 42: 437-46 (2002)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Galaxolide concentrations in eel (Anguilla anguillla) from Berlin, Germany area rivers, namely Spree and Dahme, the river Havel, and from the combined Teltow Kanal, Griegnitzsee and Fleiner Wannsee (these later three have a high proportion of wastewater) were 88.5 (max 306.0), 93.4 (max 285.0), and 1,365 (4,131) ug/kg freshweight, respectively, detection limit of 30 ug/kg fresh weight(1). Galaxolide concentration ranges in biota taken in a pond from a sewage treatment plant were as follows (ug/g lipid): rudd, 6.2-7.5; tench, 150-160; crucian carp, 440-3,600; eel, 760-830; zebra mussel, 1,700(2).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Hu Z et al; Chemosphere 84: 1630-1635 (2011) (2) Hajkova K et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 53: 390-396 (2007) (3) Li Z et al; Water Res 45(3): 1403-1413 (2011) (4) Wan Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 424-430 (2007) (5) Schmid P et al; Chemosphere 67: S16-S21 (2007)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: A concentration range of 2.9-5.3 ng/g was reported for crucian carp (Carassius auratus), silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix) and common carp (Cyprinus carpio) from the Haihe River in North China, collected from Dec 29-30, 2008; detection limit = 1.0-1.2 ng/g(1). Galaxolide was present at concentration range of 3,1-44.0 ug/kg wet wt in chub (Leuciscus cephalus), used as a bioindicator of contamination of the Vltava River, upstream and downstream from Prague, Czeck Republic. Sampling was conducted in June 2005; detection limit = 0.4 ug/g wet weight(2). The compound was reported at a concentration range of <1.3 (upstream) to 2,947 ug/kg lipid weight (downstream) in brown trout (Salmo trutta fario L.) from the Prachatice, Brohl and Pacov streams, Czech Republic. Fish were collected upstream and downstream from sewage treatment plants in 2009(3). Galaxolide concentrations were reported in 13 Chinese sturgeon (Acipenser sinensis) collected from 2003-2005 from the Yangtze River. The age of fish ranged from 17 to 25 years. Mean concentrations were as follows (organ, ng/g wet weight): liver, 4.0; adipose, 45.8; kidney, 5.3; gallbladder, 6.5; roe, 27.6. The compound was <LOQ of 1.3 ng/g wet wt in muscle, heart, gonad, stomach, and intestines. A maximum concentration of 3.5 ng/g wet wt was reported in the gill(4). Galaxolide was detected at a concentration range of 42-230 ng/g lipid weight in brown trout (Salmo trutta fario), alpine char (Salvelinus alpinus) and lake trout (S. Namayvush) from remote alpine lakes in the Grisons, Switzerland(5).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Ramirez AJ et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 28(12): 2587-2597 (2009)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Occurrence of galaxolide in US fish from five effluent-dominated rivers receiving direct discharge from WWTP and one minimally impacted river. Sampling was conducted during late summer, early fall 2006; method detection limit = 12 ng/g(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Six polycyclic musk compounds [Cashmeran (DPMI), Celestolide (ADBI), Phantolide (AHMI), Traseolide (ATII), Tonalide (AHTN), and Galaxolide (HHCB)] were analysed in marine green-lipped mussels (Perna viridis) from Hong Kong. ADBI, HHCB and AHTN were detected in almost all samples, while AHMI, ATII and DPMI were not detected. Concentrations of ADBI, HHCB and AHTN in mussels ranged from below detection limit-0.0743 (mean: 0.0246), 0.247-6.08 (mean: 1.15) and 0.0591-0.738 (mean: 0.190)mg/kg lipid weight, respectively. Mussels from two sampling sites in central Victoria Harbour contained the highest total polycyclic musk levels, suggesting that these waters are heavily influenced by domestic sewage. Concentrations of HHCB and AHTN detected in the mussel samples were the second highest and the highest levels, respectively, compared to global concentrations. A preliminary risk assessment indicated that HHCB and AHTN in mussels pose little or no threat to the health of shellfish consumers. Nevertheless, more comprehensive studies are required to further assess the ecological and human health risks associated with polycyclic musks.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Balk F, Ford RA; Toxicol Lett 111: 57-79 (1999) (2) Winkler M et al; Chemosphere 37: 1139-56 (1998) (3) Ricking M et al; Water Res 37: 2607-17 (2003) (4) Peck AM et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5629-35 (2006)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Galaxolide concentrations in sediments were 0.15-0.3 mg/kg dw (Ruhr River); 0.05 to 0.16 mg/kg dw (Rhine at Dutch border); 0.05-0.58 mg/kg dw (Meuse at Dutch border); 0.10 mg/kg dw median from suspended matter in The Netherlands surface waters; 0.15-0.75 mg/kg dw in Elbe suspended particulate materials (Germany)(1). Galaxolide has been found in association with suspended particulate matter collected from the Elbe River at Magdeburg, Germany during June 1996-May 1997 with concentrations ranging from 148 to 736 ng/g, mean of 440 ng/g(2). The compound was detected, not quantified in all sediment samples from the Havel and Spree rivers in Germany (tributaries to the Elbe River), representing the sediment record from 1979/80 up to 1995(3). Galaxolide concentrations in a sediment core from Lake Ontario (mid-lake, between Rochester, NY and Toronto, Ontario, Canada) were as follows: 0 ng/g (1870), 5 ng/g (1895), 0 ng/g (1921), 8 ng/g (1962), 0 ng/g (1977), 37 ng/g (1990), 17 ng/g (2000)(4). Galaxolide concentrations in a sediment core from Lake Erie (near-shore Canada, east of Buffalo, NY) were as follows: 1.0 ng/g (1980), 0.7 ng/g (1985), 0.8 ng/g (1990), 1.5 ng/g (1995), 0.3 ng/g (1998), 2.0 ng/g (2000), 3.5 ng/g (2003)(4). The galaxolide accumulations rate in Lake Erie for 1979-2003 and 1990-2003  correspond to doubling times of 16 and 8 years, respectively, and reflect the current US production trend of all fragrance chemicals(4).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Hu Z et al; Chemosphere 84: 1630-1635 (2011) (3) Villa S et al; Sci Total Environ 416: 137-41 (2012) (4) Li Z et al; Water Res 45(3): 1403-1413 (2011)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Galaxolide was present in 100% of 13 samples at a concentration range of 1.5-32.3 ng/g dry weight from sites along the Haihe River in North China, collected from Dec 29-30, 2008(1). A median concentration of 1349 ng/g dry weight has been reported in suspended sediments from the Molgora River (Lombardia Region, Northern Italy), sampled in 2010/2011. A median concentration of 442 ng/g dry weight was reported in suspended sediments from the Elbe River, Germany, sampled in 1997. Median concentrations of 160 and 580 ng/g dry weight were reported in suspended sediments from the Rhine and Meuse Rivers, the Netherlands, sampled in 1994-96(3). Galaxolide was reported at a concentration <0.05 (upstream) to 18.3 ug/kg dry weight (downstream) in sediments from the Prachatice, Brohl and Pacov streams, Czech Republic. Samples were collected upstream and downstream from sewage treatment plants in 2009(4).

SEDIMENT: Human activity in estuarine areas has resulted in pollution of the aquatic environment, but little is known about the levels of synthetic musks (SMs) in river water and sediments in estuarine areas. This study investigated the concentrations and distribution of SMs in the Jiaozhou Bay wetland, including celestolide, phantolide, traseolide, galaxolide (HHCB), tonalide (AHTN), musk xylene and musk ketone (MK). The SMs HHCB, AHTN and MK were detected at concentrations of 10.7-208, not detected (ND)-59.2 and ND-13.6 ng/L, respectively, in surface water samples and 13.1-27.3, 3.06-14.5 and 1.33-18.8 ng/g (dry weight; dw), respectively, in sediment samples. Based on the calculated total organic carbon (TOC) concentrations, there was no significant correlation between SMs and TOC in sediment samples (p?>?0.05). The hazard quotients were 0.204, 0.386 and 0.059 for AHTN, HHCB and MK, respectively, which indicated no serious environmental impact, because these values are all less than 1. The concentrations of SMs decreased as the distance to the Xiaojianxi refuse landfill increased in both surface water and sediments. Compared with previous studies, the concentration of SMs in the Jiaozhou Bay wetland was relatively high. Therefore, more attention should be paid to SMs because of their persistent impact on human health and the environment.
